questions.text: On uterine contraction, there is cervical dilation and Delivery. Which of the following shows similar mechanism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Milk ejection by Oxytocin. The mechanism of uterine contraction and milk ejection are both examples of a positive feedback loop. In this physiological mechanism, a stimulus triggers a response, and that response, in turn, amplifies the original stimulus, leading to a continuous cycle of increasing activity until the process is complete. In childbirth, uterine contractions lead to cervical stretching, which stimulates the release of more oxytocin, causing stronger contractions. Similarly, during lactation, the infant's suckling stimulates the release of oxytocin, which causes milk to be ejected, and the continued suckling then leads to the release of more oxytocin. Both processes are self-amplifying cycles mediated by oxytocin. This contrasts with negative feedback loops, such as water retention by ADH, which work to reverse or counteract a stimulus to maintain homeostasis. FSH secretion is also primarily regulated by a negative feedback loop. Therefore, milk ejection by oxytocin is the only option that demonstrates a similar positive feedback mechanism.

questions.text: Insulin dependent GLUT 4 transport is done by which of the following method?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: (D) Facilitated diffusion Explanation: GLUT4 is a glucose transporter protein found in insulin-sensitive tissues like muscle and adipose cells. When insulin binds to its receptor, it signals these cells to move GLUT4-containing vesicles to the cell membrane. Once at the membrane, GLUT4 acts as a channel to allow glucose to move from an area of higher concentration (outside the cell) to an area of lower concentration (inside the cell). This movement down the concentration gradient, with the help of a protein carrier, is the definition of facilitated diffusion. No direct cellular energy (ATP) is consumed in the actual transport of glucose through GLUT4. Incorrect Options: Option A. Primary active Transport Explanation: Primary active transport directly uses ATP to pump molecules against their concentration gradient. GLUT4 does not directly consume ATP to move glucose. Option B. Secondary active Transport Explanation: Secondary active transport uses the energy from an existing electrochemical gradient (often established by primary active transport) to move another molecule. GLUT4 does not rely on such a coupled gradient for glucose transport. Option C. Simple diffusion Explanation: Simple diffusion involves molecules passing directly through the lipid bilayer without the aid of transport proteins. Glucose is a relatively large and polar molecule and cannot easily cross the cell membrane by simple diffusion; it requires a specific transporter like GLUT4.

questions.text: Comment on the hormone produced by marked cells
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) These are thyroid follicles on the slide of Thyroid Gland, so the hormone produced is Thyroid hormone. Para follicular cells produce – Calcitonin

questions.text: Left shift of Oxygen dissociation curve is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Right shift of the curve will be seen – whenever there is increase in PCO2, increase in H+, decrease in pH, increase in temp, increase in 2,3- BPG Left shiftof the curve will be seen – whenever there is decrease in PCO2,decrease in H+, increase in pH, decrease in temp,decrease in 2,3 BPG

questions.text: Gower’s signis demonstrated in a child in your OPD.Work-up shows decreased/altered dystrophin protein. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD): DMD is caused by a complete or nearly complete absence of functional dystrophin protein due to specific mutations in the dystrophin gene. It is a severe, rapidly progressive form of muscular dystrophy that typically presents in early childhood with proximal muscle weakness, and Gower's sign is a hallmark feature. B. Becker's muscular dystrophy (BMD): BMD is also caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene, but these mutations result in the production of a reduced amount or a partially functional (altered) dystrophin protein. BMD is a milder, more slowly progressive form of muscular dystrophy compared to DMD, but patients can still exhibit Gower's sign and have similar, though less severe, muscle weakness. C. Congenital myopathy: This is a broad group of inherited muscle disorders that are present at birth or in early infancy. While they cause muscle weakness, they are typically associated with structural abnormalities in muscle fibers and are not primarily caused by defects in the dystrophin protein. D. All of the above: This would imply that congenital myopathy also fits the "decreased/altered dystrophin" criterion, which it does not.

questions.text: When ORS is given to the patient, Glucose is absorbed by which of the following transport mechanisms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) It is SGLT transport i.e. secondary active co-transport

questions.text: Arrange the following in right order:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) correct marked points are : 1= aortic area, 2= pulmonary area, 3= Tricuspid area, 4= Mitral area

questions.text: A30-year-old lady complains of cramps in the breast while breast Feeding. Which of the following hormones is responsible?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Oxytocin causes the contraction of the myo epithelial cells which surround the ducts, oxytocin is the probable reason of cramps in breast.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones regulates serum calcium levels?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All three hormones are responsible for regulation of serum calcium levels.

questions.text: Ingestation all if surfactant are produced by which cells?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Type 2 pneumocytes produce the surfactant in gestational life.

questions.text: A child was defecating in the open in a village when he was attacked by pack of dogs. One of the attacking dogs was found dead the next day. Considering the high risk of rabies in the child he was admitted to District hospital and was given antirabiesserum (ARS) and Rabipur vaccine. Which of the following is responsible for transport of rabies virus to brain?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rabies virus to the brain is an example of Retrograde Exoplasmic transport, with the help of protein Dynein (molecular motor) In Anterograde transport, the molecular motor used is Kinesin.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte imbalances results in increased nerve excitability?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hypocalcemia causes loss of membrane stabalising action of calcium and that increases the neuronal and muscle excitability which is called Tetany.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones can regulate release of Prolactin from the anterior pituitary?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Prolactin released by the anterior pituitary is controlled by the prolactin inhibiting factor by the hypothalamus and by the Throtropin-releasing hormone by the hypothalamus. Hypothyroidism – increase TRH - increases Prolactin

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is involved in milk ejection reflex?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Oxytocin is responsible for milk ejection. Prolactin increases the milk secretion or production.

questions.text: Thyroxine has maximum affinity for which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Thyroxine binding globulin Binding proteins for thyroxine hormone : TBG (thyroxine binding globulin), albumin, trans thyretin Thyroxine binding pre-albumin is now known as trans thyretin. T4 is maximally bind to Thyroxine binding globulin (TBG)

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the CO2 dissociation curve shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Haldane effect – Deoxy Hb (SaO2 75%) can bind more CO2 than Oxy Hb (SaO2 100%) Chloride shift and hamburger phenomenon are seen in Venous RBC’s. Bohr effect- shift of the oxygen Hb dissociation curve.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Brown-Sequard is hemisection of the spinal cord. Sensory tracts are always ascending and motor tracts are always descending.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department unconscious. An arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following results: pH 7.1, PCO2 23 mmHg, PO2 98 mmHg, HC03 16 mEq/L. What does this analysis indicate about the patient's condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Metabolic acidosis

questions.text: Which hormone increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) GH

questions.text: Which function of inhibin is accurate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Inhibition of FSH

questions.text: Which hormone is released from the zona fasciculata?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Glucocorticoid

questions.text: What are the characteristic features of primary hypothyroidism?

questions.text: A patient presented with wheezing and shortness of breath and low FEV1. Which of the following conditions will have the same?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Asthma

questions.text: A 23 year old man comes to hospital. O/E BP — 150/90 mmhg, afebrile. On further evaluation Serum Renin found normal, he is diagnosed with conns syndrome. All are true about conns syndrome except —
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Metabolic acidosis is the correct answer because it is not a feature of Conn’s syndrome. Conn’s syndrome, or primary hyperaldosteronism, involves excessive aldosterone secretion. Aldosterone promotes the excretion of hydrogen ions and potassium in the kidneys. The loss of hydrogen ions leads to metabolic alkalosis, not acidosis. Therefore, stating that metabolic acidosis occurs in Conn’s syndrome is incorrect, Metabolic alkalosis This option is incorrect because metabolic alkalosis does occur in Conn’s syndrome. The high levels of aldosterone cause the kidneys to lose hydrogen ions, which leads to a rise in blood pH and metabolic alkalosis. So, this is a true statement about Conn’s syndrome. Hypertension This option is incorrect because hypertension does occur in Conn’s syndrome. Aldosterone causes increased reabsorption of sodium and water in the renal tubules, leading to volume expansion and elevated blood pressure. Therefore, hypertension is a correct and expected feature of the condition. Low renin levels This option is incorrect because low renin levels are seen in Conn’s syndrome. The expanded blood volume and elevated blood pressure from aldosterone’s action suppress renin secretion via negative feedback. Thus, low renin is a hallmark of primary hyperaldosteronism like Conn’s syndrome.

questions.text: Kinesin, dynein and myosin protein are example of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Explanation: Kinesin, dynein, and myosin are all examples of molecular motors. These proteins use the energy from ATP hydrolysis to generate mechanical movement. They move along cytoskeletal filaments (microtubules for kinesin and dynein, and actin filaments for myosin) to transport cellular materials, enable muscle contraction, and play roles in processes like cell division. Incorrect options: A. Transcellular molecule Explanation: Transcellular molecules typically move across cells or cellular membranes (like transport proteins), which is not the primary function of kinesin, dynein, and myosin. B. Intracellular molecule Explanation: While these proteins are indeed found inside the cell, the term "intracellular molecule" does not specifically describe their function as motors. D. Cell adhesion molecule Explanation: Cell adhesion molecules (CAMs) are involved in the attachment between cells or between cells and the extracellular matrix. Kinesin, dynein, and myosin are not involved in adhesion but in movement along cytoskeletal tracks.

questions.text: Voltage gated calcium channel present on T tubule is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) is the voltage-gated calcium channel located specifically on the T-tubule membrane of skeletal muscle fibers. It acts as a voltage sensor during muscle excitation. Upon depolarization of the T-tubule, DHPR undergoes a conformational change which directly interacts with the ryanodine receptor (RyR1) on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, leading to the release of calcium into the cytoplasm and triggering muscle contraction. This makes it the correct and most precise answer.

questions.text: A mother comes to hospital with newborn baby, on examination surfactant not adequately found and collapse alveoli seen. What will be most probable diagnosis —
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS), also known as Hyaline Membrane Disease, is the most probable diagnosis in a newborn where surfactant is inadequate and alveolar collapse is observed. Surfactant reduces surface tension in the alveoli and prevents their collapse during exhalation. It is typically insufficient in premature infants, leading to alveolar collapse, impaired gas exchange, and clinical respiratory distress soon after birth. Incorrect Options: Option A: Bronchial asthma Asthma is a chronic inflammatory airway disease seen in older children and adults, not in neonates. It is characterized by bronchospasm, wheezing, and reversible airflow obstruction — not due to surfactant deficiency or alveolar collapse at birth. Option C: Pneumonia Neonatal pneumonia involves infection and inflammation of the lungs, which may cause respiratory distress, but it is not associated with surfactant deficiency or typical alveolar collapse due to immature lungs. Additionally, pneumonia would likely present with signs of infection such as fever, leukocytosis, or sepsis. Option D: Pleural effusion Pleural effusion refers to fluid accumulation in the pleural space, which can cause respiratory difficulty, but it is not caused by surfactant deficiency or associated with alveolar collapse in the context of a newborn. It would be seen on imaging as fluid, not collapsed alveoli.

questions.text: A Man ate 3 cones of ice-cream. After some time he starts felling more colder ear than central part of body. Which part of brain responsible thermo regulation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A. Thalamus: The thalamus is primarily involved in relaying sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex. Although it plays a role in sensory perception, it is not the main center for thermoregulation. B. Hypothalamus: The hypothalamus acts as the body's thermostat. It monitors core body temperature via thermoreceptors and orchestrates appropriate responses (such as shivering, sweating, and changes in blood flow) to maintain thermal homeostasis. In this case, after ingesting a large amount of cold ice-cream, the hypothalamus detects the drop in temperature in certain regions (like the ear) and signals the body to adjust accordingly. C. Amygdala: The amygdala is primarily involved in processing emotions, especially fear and pleasure. It is not directly responsible for regulating body temperature. D. Cerebellum: The cerebellum is essential for coordinating voluntary movements and maintaining balance. It does not play a direct role in thermoregulation.

questions.text: A person with history of RTA admitted in hospital. He is able to understand his friend talks. He is trying to speak something to his friend but he is unable to speak (non fluent aphasia). Which part of brain most likely to be injured in this case —
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Broca’s area is located in the posterior part of the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (usually the left). It is responsible for the motor production of speech. A lesion here leads to non-fluent (expressive) aphasia, where the patient can understand spoken language but has difficulty speaking. Speech becomes slow, effortful, and broken, often with intact comprehension. This matches the scenario described, where the patient understands his friend but is unable to express himself fluently after the trauma. Incorrect Options: A. Wernicke’s area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus, and it governs language comprehension. A lesion here causes fluent aphasia, where the patient can speak in long sentences, but the speech is often meaningless and lacks comprehension. Since the patient in the question understands others well, this option is incorrect. C. Angular gyrus is involved in visual language processing, such as reading and writing. Damage here can lead to alexia (inability to read) or agraphia (inability to write) but does not typically cause speech production issues like non-fluent aphasia, making this option unrelated to the presented case. D. Arcuate fasciculus is the white matter tract that connects Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas. Lesions here lead to conduction aphasia, where the patient has fluent speech and good comprehension but poor repetition. This is different from the non-fluent, expressive type of aphasia described in the question, hence this option is also incorrect.

questions.text: Cell membrane charge will be maintained by which of the following channels
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Na-K with primary active transport

questions.text: Which of the following factor derived from Arterial blood Gas analysis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bicarbonate

questions.text: A patient present in ER with hypotension. On auscultation dullness of heart sound and dilated neck veins diagnosed with cardiac tamponade. Which of the following finding can be seen on JVP.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In cardiac tamponade, the pericardial space is filled with fluid, which compresses the heart and restricts its normal filling, particularly during diastole. This results in elevated venous pressure and the classic finding of an absent Y descent in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform. The Y descent corresponds to early diastolic filling of the right atrium and is blunted in tamponade due to restricted filling. Why other options are incorrect: A. Rapid Y descent Explanation: A rapid Y descent would typically be seen in conditions like constrictive pericarditis, where there is restriction to ventricular filling, but not due to the same mechanism as in tamponade. In tamponade, the Y descent is absent, not rapid. C. Absent A wave Explanation: The A wave in JVP represents atrial contraction, and it is typically present in tamponade. It's not absent because atrial contraction still occurs even when there is restricted ventricular filling. D. Canon A wave Explanation: A canon A wave is associated with ventricular-atrial dissociation, such as in complete heart block or ventricular tachycardia, where the atria contract against a closed tricuspid valve. It is not seen in cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: In lumen of the venules which type of cells will be in the center?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) RBCs In blood vessels, especially smaller ones like venules, blood flows in a laminar fashion. This means that the fluid near the vessel walls moves slower due to friction, while the fluid in the center moves faster. Due to their higher concentration, biconcave shape, and deformability, red blood cells tend to aggregate and move within this faster-flowing central (axial) stream. This phenomenon is known as axial streaming. Conversely, the plasma and other blood cells, particularly leukocytes (like lymphocytes, neutrophils, and macrophages), which are less numerous and often more rigid or tend to interact with the endothelium, are pushed towards the periphery of the vessel, closer to the endothelial lining. This margination of leukocytes is a critical step in the inflammatory process, allowing them to adhere to the vessel wall and eventually exit into the surrounding tissue.

questions.text: Action of thyroid hormone is mediated by which of the following receptors?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Nuclear

questions.text: Two medical students are planning a trip to Leh (high altitude). They want to study the effects of acclimatization in high altitude. Which one of the following changes will not be seen in high altitude during the process of acclimatization?

questions.text: Identify the hormones A & B responsible for negative feedback on Hypothalamus - Pituitary axis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Inhibin & Testosterone

questions.text: On IV injection of an irritant substance, bradycardia, hypotension and apnea developed in the subject. This represents which of the following reflex?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bezold - Jarisch Reflex

questions.text: In the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform, the "a" wave corresponds to:

questions.text: In a patient after giving noradrenaline injection decrease in heart rate is observed. What is the most likely physiological mechanism responsible for this response?

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the release of bicarbonate in exchanged for chloride ions in RBC?

questions.text: Which of the following factors causes a rightward shift in the oxygen- hemoglobin dissociation curve?

questions.text: A 50-year old patient presents with respiratory difficulty and a history of chronic smoking for last 30 years. Pulmonary function testing shows a decrease in FEV1%. What is the most probable diagnosis?

questions.text: A renal biopsy image is shown. Identify the cells marked in the histological section.

questions.text: Dehydration is more severe in infants compared to adults. Which of the following is a true statement about infants?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Extracellular fluid (ECF) is more than intracellular fluid (ICF)

questions.text: A hypertensive patient's lab results reveal hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Conn’s syndrome

questions.text: During spermatogenesis, which of the following hormones inhibits Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) secretion?

questions.text: A patient had difficulty in switching from one movement to another, with uncontrollable hand movements-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dysdiadochokinesia

choices.text: Point B to Point D represents Absolute refractory period
Point C to Point E represents refractory period
Point C to Point D is mediated by Na influx

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding the image given
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)1. A. Point A represents Threshold Potential • Point A represents the resting membrane potential (~ -70 mV). • Threshold potential is marked by Point E (~ -55 mV). 2. B. Point B to Point D represents Absolute refractory period • Absolute refractory period occurs from beginning of depolarization B to half of hyperpolarization when Na? channels are either open or inactivated. • Point D is beyond this; at D, the relative refractory period is ongoing. 3. C. Point C to Point E represents refractory period • Point C is peak/repolarization, and Point E is threshold potential (which occurs earlier). • The refractory period doesn’t match this range; this statement is anatomically inconsistent. 4. D. Point C to Point D is mediated by Na? influx • Point C to D is repolarization and hyperpolarization, mainly mediated by K? efflux, not Na? influx.

questions.text: Identify the correct pair of hormones responsible for growth of the identified structures.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hormonal actions 1.Estrogen: Stimulates growth and branching of the ductal system (Mark A). Also increases deposition of fat and stroma. 2.Progesterone: Stimulates development of alveoli and lobules (Mark B). Prepares glandular tissue for milk secretion.

choices.text: She is hypoventilating; and that makes her dyspneic.
Atmospheric Oxygen in Leh is lesser than that in Delhi and that makes her hemoglobin to decrease O2 delivery to tissues; causing dyspnoea.
She is hyperventilating, causing dyspnoea and Respiratory Alkalosis
Atmospheric Oxygen in Leh is higher than that in Delhi and that makes her to experience dyspnoea.

questions.text: 28 year old woman arrives Leh Airport form Delhi. Upon Arrival, she experienced dyspnoea. Which of the following is true regarding her condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A. She is hypoventilating; and that makes her dyspneic. ? Wrong: At high altitude, patients hyperventilate, not hypoventilate. B. Atmospheric Oxygen in Leh is lesser than that in Delhi and that makes her hemoglobin to decrease O2 delivery to tissues; causing dyspnoea. ? Misleading: The atmospheric fraction of O? is the same (21%), it’s the partial pressure that is reduced. Hb delivery decreases due to hypoxemia, but wording is incorrect. C. She is hyperventilating, causing dyspnoea and Respiratory Alkalosis ? Correct: Hyperventilation is the immediate response at high altitude. This leads to low PCO? and respiratory alkalosis (seen acutely before renal compensation). Hyperventilation itself contributes to dyspnea. D. Atmospheric Oxygen in Leh is higher than that in Delhi and that makes her to experience dyspnoea. ? Wrong: Atmospheric oxygen is lower, not higher.

choices.text: Antibodies against Ach receptors at ganglions
Antibodies against Ach receptors at muscle fibres
Antibodies against Voltage gated Calcium channels in neuronal end
Antibodies against Voltage gated Calcium channels in muscle fibres

questions.text: A subject presents to OPD with complaints of drooping eyelids which gets better after sleep and worsens as day progresses. Most probable cause is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A. Antibodies against Ach receptors at ganglions ? Wrong: Myasthenia gravis is not a ganglionic disorder; it’s at the neuromuscular junction (post-synaptic). Ganglionic disorders (e.g., autoimmune autonomic ganglionopathy) cause autonomic dysfunction, not ptosis. B. Antibodies against Ach receptors at muscle fibres ? Correct: Myasthenia gravis is due to antibodies against nicotinic ACh receptors on the post-synaptic membrane of the neuromuscular junction. This prevents Ach from binding, causing fatigable weakness. C. Antibodies against Voltage gated Calcium channels in neuronal end ? This describes Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS). In LEMS: weakness improves with activity, and autonomic symptoms (dry mouth, constipation) are common. D. Antibodies against Voltage gated Calcium channels in muscle fibres ? No such mechanism; calcium channels in muscle fibres are not targeted in these diseases.

choices.text: Sodium channel abnormality causing excessive muscle activation
Increased release of calcium from sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal myocytes
Decreased ATP binding with myosin head

questions.text: Subject is diagnosed with Ryanodine receptor mutation. What is the likely abnormality that can happen with this pathophysiology?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A. Sodium channel abnormality causing excessive muscle activation ? This is not related to RyR. Sodium channel abnormalities cause periodic paralysis or channelopathies, but RyR mutation is not directly about sodium. B. Increased release of calcium from sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal myocytes ? Correct. •RyR mutation can cause excessive calcium release from the SR, leading to conditions like malignant hyperthermia: •Uncontrolled muscle contraction •Increased metabolism ? heat production •Rhabdomyolysis, hyperkalemia C. Decreased ATP binding with myosin head ? This is unrelated. ATP binding is necessary for detachment of the myosin head; defects in ATP handling lead to rigor mortis, not RyR mutation. D. Increased Calcium influx from ECF ? This is not the primary defect. RyR regulates calcium release from the SR, not influx from extracellular fluid. Voltage-gated calcium channels (DHPR) regulate extracellular influx.

choices.text: A fibres are more susceptible to pressure, followed by B fibres & C fibres equally
Pain in this condition is carried by A delta fibres.
Pain in this condition is carried by C fibres
All the nerve fibres got affected because of this pressure and that is the reason for pain.

questions.text: A subject sleeps with arm under his head. Upon waking, he notices tingling sensation and pain in his arm. Identify the correct statement regarding this condition.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1.Susceptibility of nerve fibres to pressure •Large myelinated fibres (A fibres) are more susceptible to pressure and compression. •Small myelinated (B) and unmyelinated (C fibres) are more resistant to pressure. •This is why prolonged pressure (like sleeping with the arm under the head) causes paresthesia and tingling (A-beta & A-alpha conduction block) first. 2.Pain fibres •A-delta fibres: Myelinated, fast, sharp, well-localized pain •C fibres: Unmyelinated, slow, dull, aching pain 3.In this condition, compression leads to tingling/paresthesia due to conduction block of large myelinated fibres. The pain experienced (if any) is carried by C fibres (dull aching pain) or A-delta (if sharp).

questions.text: As neuron’s diameter increases, what effect gets manifested ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1.As axon diameter increases: •Internal (axial) resistance decreases ? current flows more easily along the axon. •Conduction velocity increases because depolarization spreads faster. •Membrane resistance per unit length decreases (more surface area for ion leakage). •Action potential amplitude remains constant because it is an all-or-none phenomenon.

questions.text: A subject was brought to Casualty with history of RTA and head injury. On examination, he was conscious. When the doctor asked questions about the incident, his answers were irrelevant to the questions but his speech was fluent. What could be possible site of injury?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A. Pre-central gyrus •? This is the primary motor cortex. Lesion causes contralateral motor weakness, not language comprehension problems. B. Inferior frontal gyrus •? This is the site of Broca’s area (motor speech). Lesion here leads to non-fluent, effortful speech with intact comprehension (expressive aphasia). •But in this case, speech is fluent ? not Broca’s. C. Superior temporal gyrus •? This is the site of Wernicke’s area (area 22, dominant hemisphere). •Lesion here leads to: •Fluent but meaningless speech (word salad) •Poor comprehension •Answers irrelevant to questions (receptive aphasia) •Matches the question perfectly. D. Basal ganglia •? Causes movement disorders (Parkinsonism, chorea) but not classical language deficits.

choices.text: Chill cold weather & Airway hypersensitivity - Bronchoconstriction

questions.text: A subject works out in a chill cold weather. He developed dyspnoea. Choose the correct statement regarding this condition
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A. Work out - Sympathetic Stimulation - Bronchoconstriction • ? Sympathetic stimulation causes bronchodilatation, not constriction. B. Work out - Sympathetic Stimulation - Bronchodilatation • ? Although sympathetic stimulation causes bronchodilatation, this does not explain dyspnea in cold-induced bronchospasm. C. Work out - Parasympathetic Stimulation - Bronchodilatation • ? Parasympathetic stimulation causes bronchoconstriction, not dilatation. D. Chill cold weather & Airway hypersensitivity - Bronchoconstriction • ? Correct. • Cold air + airway hypersensitivity leads to bronchoconstriction (via parasympathetic reflexes and release of mediators). • This is the basis of exercise-induced bronchospasm seen in asthmatics and sensitive individuals.

questions.text: Patient presents with dizziness and palpitations. ECG recording shows irregularly irregular rhythm and absent P waves. What finding will be seen in this patient’s jVP?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Absent a wave • ? Correct: AF ? absent organized atrial contraction ? absent a wave. B. Cannon a wave • ? Seen in complete heart block or AV dissociation when atria contract against closed AV valves. C. Prominent a wave • ? Seen in tricuspid stenosis or pulmonary hypertension (strong atrial contraction against resistance). D. Absent Y descent • ? Seen in cardiac tamponade (due to restricted ventricular filling).
